characters: THE ENTIRE PRECINCT EXPLODES IN A HUGE CONFLAGRATION
OF TERROR ENDS AS MYERS PERISHES IN VIGILANTE EXPLOSION."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agonizing SCREAMS continue as we MOVE rapidly through labyrinth of winding underground tunnels.  Glowing torche the way.  Blurry, indistinct silhouettes of grim FIGURES black-cowled robes flash along the dank, craggy walls. As we BLAST around dark corners, we realize we are lookin the P.O.V. of a SCREAMING young woman being pushed forwar gurney.  Plunging deeper into this hellish maze. A door is SLAMMED.  Wooden.  Heavy.  Muffling the SCREAMS Spurs CLANK on a pair of silver-tipped cowboy boots as a  MYSTERIOUS STRANGER steps into VIEW.  Long black duster. Widebrimmed fedora.  Lit cigarette dangling between glove fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rat scampers from a hole, foraging in the muck of a rot rack.  A white sheet, saturated with blood, covers the pa of JAMIE LLOYD, now 16, cheeks flushed with perspiration.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God, it's coming!  It's coming! MARY, a young midwife, rushes in with a bowl of hot water lurches, knocking the bowl out of the girl's hands; it SH the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mary, mother of God, please make it stop! Mary's face is frozen in horror.  Jamie's SCREAMS build t unnerving crescendo.  The paiin too much for her to bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lurid SHOCK CUTS from the previous "Halloween" entries -- surrealistic blend of IMAGES and VOICES -- as Jamie reliv terrifying childhood ordeal:

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... Ten years ago he tried to kill Laurie  Strode ... A)   LAURIE STRODE (Jamie Lee Curtis) twists and squirms strangled mercilessly in the hands of the murderous SHAPE

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... Now he wants her daughter. B)   Trapped in her bedroom, 10-YEAR-OLD JAMIE (Danielle struggles to open the door.  She flings it open.  The Sha standing there, knife poised to kill!

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Michael Myers is here to kill that little girl  and anyone else who gets in his way! C)   RACHEL (Ellie Cornell) dies in anguish as the Shape pair of scissors through her chest.  TINA (Wendy Kaplan) right into the path of the Shape's knife.  "Jamie, run!!! D)   Jamie sinks to her knees behind the fallen Shape, ta hand in her own.  CLOSE ON the Shape's hand.  Fingers fle life.  A grotesque BRAND on its wrist -- an inverted isoc triangle that will come to be known as the mark of THORN. E)   BLINDING EXPLOSION rips through cinderblock.  A jail to oblivion.  FIRESTORM rages.  The MYSTERIOUS STRANGER a opening fire with a SEMI-AUTOMATIC RIFLE. Pitiful wails of death.  OFFICERS writhing in pools of bl the aftermath of this carnage stands YOUNG JAMIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie struggles against her bonds.  Pushing.  SCREAMING. in and out of consciousness during the excruciating pangs labor.  Haunted by low, moaning VOICES.  CHANTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME Jamie, filled with repidation as she staggers thro smoke-filled cell into a darkened, drizzly alleyway. JAMIE'S P.O.V. Beyond the clearing wisps of smoke, THREE FIGURES wearing ski masks usher THE SHAPE -- arms and legs shackled in he chains -- into the back of a white van.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Mutely terrified, Jamie backs away -- into the arms of an figure, obscured by smokescreen:  the Mysterious Stranger Jamie's scream is cut off as the Stranger descends upon h the Angel of Death. A cigarette arcs throug the darkness like a tiny flare. under the boot of the Stranger. A moment later, Jamie is shoved into the front seat of th Doors SLAM.  Tires SCREECH over wet pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SLAP and the first cry of the newborn BABY.  Jamie sobs uncontrollably, the straps preventing her from reaching h

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Please ... give him to me ... The infant is wrapped in black swaddling.  The wooden doo open.  Jamie's eyes fill with horror as the shadow of the fills the room.  Standing at the threshold.  Waiting to r the child.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) No, please ... my baby! The dark sentinels march out in somber procession, ignori desperate pleas.  Torches lighting the way.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Damn you!!  Damn you all to hell!!! Jamie's heartrending SHRIEKS are cut off by the cold soun SLAMMING DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN TITLE SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: A diaphanous column rises, a ghostly, slow-motion cylinde flame that BURNS through the SCREEN to form the MAIN TITL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OPENING CREDITS are BRANDED against the BLACK SCREEN invisible, kenetic force, interspersed with a SERIES OF C Jamie's baby is lain upon a primitive altar.  Ringed by e stones engraved with cryptic markings. Hooded, faceless figures.  Torches held aloft.  Disembodi VOICES.  Whispering.  Invoking a dark spell. MARY, the young midwife, peers around a corner.  Eyes gla horror.  Watching.  Spying. The newborn SCREAMS.  The flattened blade of a dagger sme triangular symbol in blood over the baby's torso. We MOVE IN on this symbol, capturing it in FREEZE FRAME. off into fiery cinders, disintegrating into DARKNESS. Silence.  Then a startling CLAP OF THUNDER as we

dialogues.speaker: A SIGN POST
dialogues.text: standing askew in a matted patch of lawn.  WIND and RAIN. FLASH of LIGHTNING illuminates: "For Sale By Strode Realty - SOLD" EXT/INT. MYERS HOUSE - SUBJECTIVE P.O.V. MOVE along a trail of drowning toys -- baseball, Power Ra deck of Pogs -- TOWARD a weather-beaten porch.  Leftover of Sears Best.  Brushes soaking in turpentine.  A dozen o 2s l;ined up to replace a row of broken railing slats. P.O.V. LOOKS UP to the tall, brooding edifice.  Address r Lampkin Lane.  Fresh coat of white paint over old clapboa shutters on the narrow windows.  A jack-o'-lantern grins filmy curtains.  The Myers house. Despite its recent face-lift, it looks just as foreboding did in "Halloween I." P.O.V. stalks down the side of the house, around to the b door.  Opens it and quietly MOVES inside. P.O.V. MOVES across the darkened kitchen.  A drawer is op LIGHTNING reveals a large butcher knife being withdrawn. P.O.V. glides past the living room -- a few boxes, furnit arranged -- and MOVES swiftly UP a long flight of stairs. Down the long, dark hallway ... through a door.  A bedroo P.O.V. FINDS 6-year-old DANNY STRODE ... tossing and turn the throes of a nightmare. An ear-splitting THUNDER CRASH causes the boy to bolt upr bed, looking right into the P.O.V.  Sweating.  Shaking.   Petrified. DANNY'S P.O.V. The THUNDER seems to ROAR from the ferocious jaws of T-RE 24" scale model posing on a shelf among an army of Jurass monsters.  Seemingly brought to life by the ELECTRICAL ST

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW DANNY
dialogues.text: as he leaps out of bed and pads across polished wooden fl the hallway.  LIGHTNING FLASHES.  With the next THUNDER C comes a startling, barely intelligible VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERING VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Danny ... Danny freezes.  Slowly turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ominous shadow at the end of the hall, illuminated by  LIGHTNING.  Long duster and brimmed hat.  The Stranger! outstretched hand, the gleaming butcher knife!

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERING VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Kill for him!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Danny screams!  THUNDER CRASHES HELLISHLY.  Lights flash Doors fly open.  Suddenly Danny is swept up in the protec of his mother, KARA, 22.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Danny! The little boy holds onto her for dear life.  Crying  hysterically.  Eyes clenched tightly.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Shh.  Mommy's here.  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The voice man!  He's here! Kara looks in the direction he's pointing.  In the light just an antique coat rack -- "dressed" in a hat, rain jac old silver-tipped umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Danny, no one's there. Danny dares to look -- but now only cries harder. Kara carries Danny back to his room, averting the steely- of her father, JOHN STRODE, staunch, late 40s, wearing bo shorts and a well-worn undershirt.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Some of us have to get some sleep around  here.  What's with that kid? Kara ignores him as her mother, DEBRA, careworn face with compassionate eyes, tries to lend a hand.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: Let me take him for you, Kara.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: It's all right, Mom.  Go back to bed. Debra sighs resignedly.  TIM, 18, stocky and streetwise, torn red sweat pants and "Ice-T" t-shirt, casually replac Walkman headphones and returns to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara opens the closet and switches on the light.  Satisfy that it's empty, she breaks into her perfunctory routine.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Stay away monters, stay away ghouls. Stay away  from Danny.  You jerks know the rules.  (crossing to Danny's bed) Better? Danny giggles as his pretty young mother tucks him in.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mommy, when can we go home? Kara sighs.  They've been through this one before.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Home is here in Grandma and Grandpa's new  house.  At least while I'm in college.   Remember our deal.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The kids at school said this is a haunted  house -- that a bad man used to live here.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: They did, did they?  Since when did we start  listening to the kids at school?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: But I've seen him!

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: You've been watching too much TV.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He says things.  Bad things.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Like what? Danny is afraid to tell her.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: (continuing) If you mean the things Grandpa says sometimes,  ignore him.  Once he gets to know you he'll  come around ... Let the bad things you hear  slide right off your back. Kara tousles his blond hair and kisses his forehead.  The goes to the closet, just about to turn out the light --

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sitting up; panicked) No, Mom -- keep it on!

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Okay ... But just for tonight. Kara adjusts the closet door, causing one of Danny's scho drawings to fly off the wall.  She picks it up on her way

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Good-night, Danny. Kara softly closes the door.  Danny lies awake, blankets to his chin, eyes wide.  Still very much afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara yawns, removes her glasses and rubs her eyes, settin drawing on a pile of open books.  Cliffs Notes and Diet C cans.  Telltale signs of a late-night cram session. Adjusting the dial on her FM/alarm clock, Kara begins to about the little room, slipping out of her clothes as the subtly-seductive voice of a WOMAN comes over the radio:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know this sounds crazy, Harry, but I love  him.  I write to him every week. I think I  even want to have his child -- The woman is cut off by the nasally, steel-trap voice of SIMMS, talk radio's most popular man of controversy:

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight, Debi.  Now you're  saying that not only does this guy get you  sexually aroused, but now you want to bear his  offspring?! Wearing only her bra and panties, Kara moves to a full-le mirror and lets down her long, flaxen hair.  Beneath her exterior, she is quite attractive:  delicate features wit enviable, naturally-toned figure.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Deep down, he's just like you and me. He just  needs someone to understand him.  Someone to  love him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You're talking about one of this nation's most  notorious serial killers like he belongs in  some kind of Est seminar!  What planet have  you been on, lady?  Michael Myers has been  dead for six years! A CLICK as the woman is abruptly DISCONNECTED. Kara suddenly whirls around, startled by a FLASH of somet face -- in the mirror! Drawn to the window behind her, she rubs off rainy mist a outside. KARA'S P.O.V. of the large Victorian frame house directly across the st Another FLASH OF LIGHTNING reveals the shadow of a man st the uppermost window -- looking right at her!

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Frightened, her eyes lock on Danny's drawing.  A child's  scribbling in red Crayon:  The triangular symbol of Thorn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara draws the priscilla curtains over the window as we P through the pouring RAIN ... toward the house across the An ornate sign on the front door reads: "Blankenship House - Rooms Available" CRANE UP toward the window where the shadowy figure stand insidious CRASH OF THUNDER as we PUSH through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A macabre display of old newspaper headlines, arranged  helterskelter on a wall:  "HALLOWEEN KILLS ESCAPES FROM A

dialogues.speaker: OF TERROR ENDS AS MYERS PERISHES IN VIGILANTE EXPLOSION."
dialogues.text: Harry Simms BOOMS over a state-of-the-art HiFi system.  A tape RECORDS the continuing broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now we've got someone who claims he's actually  seen Michael Myers.  Does this whacko caller  have a name? Staring out the window at the Myers house, TOMMY DOYLE, a strapping 25-year-old with reddish brown hair and intense cradles a cordless phone.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: My name's Tommy.  I was only eight- years-old  when I saw him.  But I was lucky.  I survived. Tommy paces nervously around his sparsely-furnished attic apartment.  Classic horror movie one-sheets and mint firs comic books share wall space with a chilling array of gun knives, and survivalist weapons.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sounds like you're a candidate for  electroshock therapy, Tommy.  Don't tell me  after all this time you still believe Myers is  alive?! Tommy pauses, mesmerized by one of the newspaper clipping

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Michael's work isn't finished in Haddonfield.   Now it's just a matter of time before he comes  home to kill again.  But this time I'll be  ready. MOVE IN TIGHT on the headline, frail and yellowed by age: "November 1, 1978.  TOMMY DOYLE SURVIVES BABYSITTER BLOOD Directly beneath this:  "November 3, 1989.  JAMIE LLOYD F

dialogues.speaker: DEAD IN POLICE STATION MASSACRE."
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a photograph of young Jamie and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie remains strapped to the table, wrapped in bloody sh Eyes closed.  Deathly still.  Suddenly an urgent, WHISPER pierces the darkness:

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERING VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Jamie?  Jamie?! Jamie startles awake to see the midwife frantically relea straps.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Come with me if you want to save your baby. Jamie can't believe her eyes.  Mary opens a threadbare kn revealing the baby inside! A soul-shuddering RUMBLE echoes throughout the cavern.  J leaps up, eyes wide with fear, sensing the evil presence.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God ... He's coming!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We've got to move.  Now! Pulsing with adrenaline, Jamie harnesses the knapsack ove shoulders and follows Mary out into the tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: TUNNEL GATE
dialogues.text: Chains GRIND over rusted pulleys.  A massive iron gate ri revealing a pair of filthy work boots.  Legs planted in b stance as a tall, ominous shape begins to emerge.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER TUNNEL
dialogues.text: The terrified midwife leads Jamie with her baby on a brea flight through the winding network of tunnels.  Haunted b ECHOING SOUNDS of the rising gate.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH TUNNELS
dialogues.text: Gliding forward into the hollow catacombs.  Slow by deter Sensing the way.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PART OF THE TUNNELS
dialogues.text: Reaching a corner, Mary stops and sends Jamie off in the direction.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: There!  It's that way!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Save your baby -- go now! Jamie runs, disappearing down the dark tunnel.  Mary quic removes her shoes and tears off, now SILENT. STALKING P.O.V. surges around a corner.  FINDS Mary.  MOVES IN on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns in small circles.  Fear mounting as she falter darkness.  Heavy, labored BREATHING fills the tunnel. A mask -- the pale, neutral features of a man weirdly dis the rubber -- materialized out of the void right behind h

dialogues.speaker: SHAPE
dialogues.text: Mary turns, about to scream when the Shape lunges out, li up by the nape of the neck and SLAMS her forehead into a metal SPIKE jutting out from the cavern wall! Leaving her impaled like a fish on a hook, the Shape resu relentless pursuit.  Eerie under the lighted torches.

dialogues.speaker: END OF TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Jamie runs frantically.  Methodical, heavy FOOTSTEPS behi She chances a look behind.  The Shape is coming! Jamie vaults up a dark stairwell.  A trap door above.  It budge.  Jamie frantically POUNDS against the hatch. The Shape mounts the stairs! Strength fueled by sheer desperation, Jamie forces the do Tumbles onto muddy ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie drags herself out of the hole and half-runs, half-s with her baby through an ugly, charred forest.  Sharp bra whip at her face.  RAIN falls.  LIGHTNING streaks across As if hell-spawned, the Shape emerges from the undergroun and trudges forward, bold and unstoppable. Jamie tumbles into a gully, nearly dropping the knapsack. picks herself up, hands groping at rain-sopped earth.  Th is right behind her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slap-happy, overweight MOTORIST sips coffee from a 7-11 straining to see the road through falling rain and fogged glasses.  Harry Simms keeps him mindlessly occupied.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Next up is Dwayne.  What's on your feeble  excuse for a mind, "Dwayne?" The Motorisft lets out a hardy GUFFAW, spilling his coffe

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Shit! Fingers burning, he searches the glove compartment for a

dialogues.speaker: DWAYNE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd just like to say that I listen to your  show every night, Harry.  I think you're the  best.  I can't tell you how excited we are  that you'll be paying a visit to our little  town tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you have a point to make here, Dwayne, or  should I just keep practicing my wrist  exercises?

dialogues.speaker: DWAYNE
dialogues.text: (chortles) Harry, you're too much.  I'd just like to say  that I understand how things have changed in  the 90's.  Gays in the military, cut off your  husband's do- jigger, become a national hero.   But I just can't see any sense in bringing  Halloween back to Haddonfield. The Motorist looks up.  Eyes go wide with panic.  Startle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie stands in the middle of the road, SCREAMING bloody-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tires SCREECH.  The pickup stops on a dime.  The Motorist sits there, mouth agape as the shrieking girl throws open and clambers into the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Drive!  Goddamnit, drive! Through his side-view mirror, the unsuspecting Motorist s outline of a quickly-approaching man.  Unrolling his wind rubbernecks a look outside.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Hey, what do you think you're -- CRUNCHING BONE and TEARING FLESH as the Shape's hands sho through the window, twisting the man's head off his shoul Jamie SCREAMS!  Lunges for the steering wheel.  Slams her down hard on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup bullets forward, fishtailing up the road, neve down as the driver's door flies open, dumping the motoris headless bulk into a muddy ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie drives.  Checks to see that her baby is safe.  Then a PRIMAL SCREAM.  A hysterical release of fear and rage, out by the squabble of VOICES over the radio:

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER
dialogues.text: You're coming here for this Halloween fair --  it's all just a game -- a publicity stunt for  you, isn't it Harry?  These kids -- they're  not old enough to remember what Myers did  here. They look up to you.  Now you're just  asking for trouble.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You people really get me.  What are they  putting in the water in that town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIGHTNING FLASHES and RAIN pelts the windows of a bucolic This is a man's retreat and has been for years.  Dark woo leather, a few tastefully-chosen antiques.  Floor-to-floo shelves containing a myriad of books and an impressive di awards and degrees, all bearing the name:  SAMUEL J. LOOM After a STATION IDENTIFICATION, "The Harry Simms Show" re tinny-voiced CALLERS blaring over a handsomely-restored 1 Bremer-Tully.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER
dialogues.text: All these fanatics aside, Harry, I'd  personally like to thank whoever did the  masked one in.  Saved us tax-payers a lot of  money in the long run.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CALLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, that sucker's been dead for six years.   It's about time they had a Halloween revival  in this town.  Now my kids can stop driving me  crazy! MOVE IN behind a bald, sharp-featured man, hunched over a he reminisces over a collection of framed photographs -- of his wife and children.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER
dialogues.text: What happened to that psychiatrist of his?   Loomis, I think was his name.  I heard the old  quack was dead. Turning at the mention of his name is DR. LOOMIS himself, spectacles, a comfortable sweater and his trademark goate the first time ever, we actually see him smile.  The burn his face have all but faded away.  Last traces of the hor

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Not dead.  Just very much retired. Loomis hobbles to the desk and finishes cutting out a new article.  As he arranges the strips of paper in a leather scrapbook, a sudden KNOCK at the door gives him a startle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ominous FIGURE, clad in hat and trench coat, stands be glowing porch light, silhouetted in the pouring RAIN. Loomis opens the door, eyes straining in the semi-darknes to identify his unexpected visitor.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: (sudden recognition) What the devil?!  Come in -- come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuffling inside, dripping with rain, DR. TERENCE WYNN, a well-dressed gentleman in his 50s, removes his hat and co quickly making himself at home by the crackling fire.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Christ, what a night!  Not even so much as a  sign for five miles on that road!

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: That's the whole idea of living in the  country.  I thrive on the seclusion. Wynn heads for the kitchen, rummaging through cabinets an as Loomis dutifully wipes up his muddy trail.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't tell me that the reviled Rasputin of  Smith's Grove has grown complacent in his  golden years.  I don't buy it for a single  second, Dr. Loomis. Loomis immediately senses that Wynn has an angle.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: And in all these years, I've never known you  to make house calls, Dr. Wynn.  Especially at  this hour ... Wynn returns with a bottle of Irish whiskey and two shot Thrusts one in Loomis's hand and begins to pour.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Unlike you, Sam, I learned many years ago not  to second-guess the motives of my fellow man.   Remember what Freud said:  'Sometimes a cigar  is just a cigar.'  Or, in this case, a drink  is just a drink.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I hope you didn't come all the way out here in  this storm just to quote Freud.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: As always, your keen powers of perception  astound me.  And you're right.  I've come to  celebrate.  (raising his glass) After thirty-two years as Psychiatric  Administrator, guess who has been named  Smith's Groves new Chief of Staff.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: But surely Rogers isn't --

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Retiring. Loomis is abruptly stunned and delighted by the news.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Why -- congratulations!  I can think of no one  better suited for the position. The two old sparring partners drink to the occasion.  But angle soon comes to the helm.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Of course, I need a new Administrator. Someone  who can bring new life -- and some old blood,  if you'll pardon the expression -- back to our  program ... Loomis prepares himself for the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: (continuing) We need you, Dr. Loomis.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: You should know that it's not wise to play  Halloween pranks on me.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: You're the only man for the job, Sam. Things  haven't been the same since you left.  I'm  recruiting the best psychiatric team in the  country.  Old colleagues.  This is your change  to finally make a difference. Loomis scratches his head and settles down into his comfo easy chair, amused at the irony of Wynn's speech.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Even after my stroke six years ago they  practically had to hold a gun to my head to  get me to retire.  Now things have changed.   I've changed.  The ghosts have been buried.   Why on earth would I want to dig them up  again? Loomis finally looks over at Wynn, surprised to find him at the desk, looking through his scrap book.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Seems to me there's at least one ghost that's  still lurking in your closet. We follow Wynn's gaze down toward the open page.  A blazi tabloid headline:  "MICHAEL MYERS - DEAD OR ALIVE?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie's getaway truck ROARS around a bend, tearing up a d stretch of highway.  The STORM rages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie strains to see as she drives through sheets of RAIN weary, fighting panic, holding one hand steady against th the other on the CRYING infant.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: God ... Help us, please ... Something up ahead.  Jamie's face fills with expectancy.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: A lighted sign appears out of the darkness.  Glowing salv Familiar red-white-and-blue logo.  "GREYHOUND."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup drives into the glow of orange vapor lights. a stop in a deserted parking lot.  Jamie staggers out, cr the knapsack as she runs toward the old depot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie blasts through double glass doors.  But the bus sta devoid of life.  Empty benches.  Blank ARRIVAL/DEPARTURE  signboard.  The low hum of vending machines. Jamie moves toward the ticket counter.  A handwritten sig the attendant:  "BACK IN 20." Shivering, holding her baby, Jamie enters an old-fashione booth.  Picks up the receiver and immediately dials 911.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You have reached Haddonfield Emergency  Services.  Due to severe weather conditions,  all circuits are momentarily busy.  If this is  not an emergency, please dial directly ... Jamie slams the phone down in terrified frustration.  Sud becomes aware of the radio program.  Piped in over ancien loudspeakers:

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For anyone who gives a flying circus, this is  Harry Simms -- the light in your night, the  love of your loins -- and I want to hear from  more of you bogeyman believers out there.  So  give me your best shot at 1-800-878-7274.  That's 1-800-URTRASH! The STATION IDENTIFICATION cuts in.  Jamie picks up the r frantically dials the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynn doesn't give up the sales pitch even as Loomis leads door.  The radio program still squawking in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: But with Rogers and his house of hacks gone,  you'd make the rules.  Just think it over.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Please try to understand, Terence. I've already  made up my mind. As Wynn continues to talk, his voice trailing off into no Loomis's attention is diverted to the VOICES on the radio

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So they're trying to kill you and your baby.   Don't tell me.  Your name also happens to be  Rosemary.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (intense whisper) No -- please listen!  They're coming ... coming  for me and my baby. Loomis's eyes widen; a man possessed.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come on, sweetheart -- what is this? Who's  coming?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's ... Michael ...  (releasing) ... Michael Myers! Loomis staggers.  A lifetime of nightmares coming back to all at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRESS IN TIGHT ON TOMMY in bed.  Listening through headph Sitting upright.  Thunderstruck.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Somebody help me!  Dr. Loomis, are you out  there?  Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynn watches with rapt attention as Loomis unlocks his sa withdraws a metal case.  He pops it open, revealing his t Magnum and a box of cartridges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus has arrived.  The ATTENDANT returns to his post.  J up the phone, filled with trepidation as PASSENGERS file strung-out ROCKER.  A pair of stern-faced NUNS.  A PRETTY greeted in the loving arms of her BOYFRIEND. Just as she is about to step out of the phone booth, a TA back turned, wearing a hat and black trench coat, moves t outside the booth!  Jamie freezes. Securing her baby in the knapsack, Jamie throws open the Suddenly the Tall Man steps in her path!

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN
dialogues.text: Are you all right, young lady? Shaking uncontrollably, Jamie shrinks away.  Backing down hall through the door marked "LADIES ROOM."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water runs into a grimy basin.  Unable to contain her tea washes the newborn.  Takes a roll of paper towels and tri the triangular blood mark off his chest. Suddenly the lights go out.  Jamie gasps.  Clutching her turns off the faucet and melts into the darkness. The door CREAKS open.  FOOTSTEPS echo inside.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: has locked herself inside one of the stalls.  Heart pound FOOTSTEPS grow louder.  Jamie's eyes dart frantically. STALKING P.O.V. MOVING methodically past the row of stalls, pushing open revealing that they are all empty.  A CRASH from the last P.O.V. moves toward it.  RUSTLING and MOVEMENT inside. A HAND pushes on the door.  An open window above the toil is gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie trembles off a stack of crates piled beneath the wi dashes around the side of the depot. Suddenly the bus ROARS by, sending up a muddy wave as it disappearing down the highway. Jamie moves swiftly across the parking lot, clutching the She throws open the door of the pickup and jumps into the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slapping down the locks, Jamie thrusts the key into the i The engine REVS to life.  She guns it, peeling out of the lot.  Back toward the highway. She drives on, suppressing her tears, stealing glances at knapsack bunched up on the passenger's seat.  Then she tu looks forward with concentrated attention. JAMIE'S P.O.V. A sign looms ahead:  "Haddonfield Memorial Hospital - 10

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jamie sighs with relief, steadying the wheel just as -- HIGHBEAMS flash on right behind her, a juggernaut roaring blackness!  Jamie's eyes flood with terror.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: The grill of a familiar white van shoots forward, SLAMMIN against the pickup's rear bumper.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: is jolted forward in her seat.  Holding on the wheel with white-knuckle grip as she's repeatedly hit from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unseen madman noses forward, veering sharply over the yellow line, scraping sides with the truck. Headlights sear a path through the night, locked in neck- profile.  SPARKS flashing at 70-miles-per-hour. The van forces Jamie onto the shoulder.  It leaves the ro branches from trees.  Jamie SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quick-cut MONTAGE, events ticking out in fractions of a like a nightmare: The pickup springboards over a gulch and slams down hard, spinning in waves of mud, careening through a vast field. pumpking patch. The van reappears in a glare of headlights.  Its engine s with fire-breathing rage. The pickup puts on a furious burst of speed.  Eating up p spinning out chunks of splattering seeds and pulp. The van bears down hard, slingshotting across the field, past the pickup, cutting right in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something heavy is thrown from the back of the van right windshield! Glass EXPLODES!  Jamie SCREAMS, hands going up instinctiv protect her face.  Swerving wildly out of control. She looks to see a sprawling, mutilated corpse on top of cold, lifeless eyes -- Mary!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup rockets at breakneck speed toward the edge of Suddenly -- JAMIE'S P.O.V. The Shape stands in the field, tall and unmoving, white m hideously in the rush of oncoming headlights.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The truck plows into the Shape, dragging it under, SLAMMI into the trunk of a huge oak tree. Everything is abruptly and shockingly silent.  Like a pha night, the van is gone.  The Shape nowhere to be seen. Steam billows from the pickup, engine TICKING, a heap of glass and mangled steel.  Pinned against the base of the shape in human form -- a scarecrow! MOVE IN on Jamie, face-down against the steering wheel. the noxious fumes, she stirs back to life.  Slowly, painf shoulders the door.  Falls onto the ground. A SPARK ignites.  BLINDING FLASH as the gas tank EXPLODES the truck ablaze.  Jamie turns, her face a frozen rictus Debris rains down on her. Suddenly a grim shadow rises from the field.  The Shape - an enormous butcher knife! Jamie rolls onto her back, SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No -- NO!!! Suddenly the knife plunges down and lands with a terrible

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knapsack catches fire ... but inside there is no baby roll of paper towels from the bus depot.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCARECROW
dialogues.text: burns; mocking Jamie with its grinning, hand-painted face

dialogues.speaker: THE SHAPE
dialogues.text: looks at us, white mask scintillating against blinding ra SUNLIGHT.  Rivulets of blood drip off a large carving kni PULLING BACK, we see it is a life-sized, knife-wielding e Michael Myers, sitting astride the "For Sale by Strode Re sign.  Stage blood spells out the words:  "He's coming!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Strode looks up with disgust as he inspects the grim that's been left on his front lawn during the night.  Puf cigarette, wearing slippers and a flimsy bath robe, John large axe. A group of neighborhood KIDS -- some dressed in Halloween costumes -- stand a safe distance away.  Gathered on the Gawking, whispering, tittering. John angrily swings the axe into the signpost.  The kids collective start.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Enough ...  (one CHOP) ... of this ...  (two CHOPS) ... Michael Myers ...  (timber) ... shit! Suddenly the sign crashes down -- and "Michael Myers" wit kids huddle.  John turns on them, brandishing the axe.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You stinkin' kids got three seconds to get the  hell off my property!  One, two -- That's all it takes.  The kids scatter, tripping over one they tear off down the black. Satisfied with himself, John stubs out his cigarette and sign and its now-headless rider to the trash. Then he trudges up the porch steps, dropping the axe as h the house.  Uttering oaths under his breath. BOOM UP over the surrounding neighborheed.  SUPERIMPOSE: "Haddonfield, Illinois.  Halloween." Last night's storm has given way to an incredibly bright picturesque morning.  CHILDREN pour out of their homes, b with excitement, dressed in colorful costumes. Even the Myers house, with its trimmed hedges and fresh c paint, somehow manages to look invite. A white van slowly rolls up the street.  WKNB logo, strea large orange banner proclaiming:  "HADDONFIELD JUNIOR COL HARVEST FAIRE '95 - See Harry Simms Live - October 31." now-familiar voice booms over loudspeaker:

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Hard Harry Simms harping on ya from the  Big Apple.  Tonight's the night and the place  to be is the First Annual Harvest Faire.  So  come on out of your broom closets, 'Fielders,  and bogey the night away with me.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER
dialogues.text: Harry, I just won first prize for ugliest  costume!  Guess who I'm dressed as.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your mother?

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER
dialogues.text: No, man -- You!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car bearing an official state emblem stops outside an i curtain of security gates.  A large sign reads:  "SMITH'S

dialogues.speaker: WARREN COUNTY SANITARIUM."
dialogues.text: A hand reaches out and waves a plastic key card in front infrared scanner.  Surveillance cameras perched on the wa As the gate yawns open and the car drives through, we SEE in the distance -- the entire perimeter bounded by woods wire fences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynn drives.  Loomis in the passenger seat, fueling his o anxieties.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: It was her voice.  On the radio.  It was  Jamie.  Calling for me.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: You don't know that for sure.  It could have  been anyone.  A practical joke. Kids.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: It was Jamie Lloyd.  She came back, as I knew  she would one day.  And whatever has brought  her back has brought Michael back as well.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: After six years?  Sam, she died with him in  that explosion after the --

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: That's what someone wants us to believe, but I  tell you Michael is alive.  I feel him.  I  sense the evil that lives inside, just as I did  all those years as I watched him.  Sitting  behind these very same walls.  Staring. Growing  stronger.  (off Wynn's silence) As my colleague, as my friend, please. I can't  go through this again.  Not alone.  I need your  help to stop him. Wynn stares.  Loomis's words fall on him like a death sen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold insignia on mahogany doors:  "TERENCE WYNN - CHIEF O Wynn and Loomis stride through a plush reception area.  D attractive, high-energy secretary, keeps pace, taking not Wynn his briefcase, phone messages, etc.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Cancel all my appointments.  Get Dr. Loomis  anything he needs -- files, tests, records of  every treatment ever administered to a former  patient of ours -- Michael Myers.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: (stunned) Michael Myers? Wynn stops abruptly before heading out the door.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: That's right.  We think there's a very good  chance he might still be alive. Loomis acknowledges Wynn's silent understanding.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Wynn and Loomis move along a sterile white corridor.  Wyn key card to BUZZ them through a series of metal security retinue of DOCTORS and NURSES fall in behind.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Notify Haddonfield's sheriff; tell him we're on  our way.  I want the entire staff on alert.  We  go to code red lockdown for twenty-four hours.  (beat) If he is alive, I plan on bringing him back.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Or what's left of him. They cut down a sub-passageway and out a fire exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loomis and Wynn dash across a windswept field where a Smi medical transport helicopter awaits them.  The deafening spinning rotors as a TECHNICIAN refuels. The doctors step inside.  The doors close and the helicop off, rising high above the cluster of the white coats bel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blender whips up a revolting concoction of chocolate Yo banana yogurt and chewy Gummi-worms as Tim, wearing Levi' and a "Harry Simms Kicks Ass" T-shirt, raps on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Bro', I knew Harry when we lived in the city.   Don't worry -- he'll be there. We've got  everything arranged.  Get with me tonight at  the fair and I'll hook you up.  Peace. Tim hangs up, guzzling down his shake as Debra navigates setting out the breakfast dishes as Kara tries to study. John, dressed in what might be a respectable business sui him better, mutters grumpily as he pours himself a cup of

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Shitheads ... Defacing my property.  I showed  them ...

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: Relax, John.  They were just kids.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Kids are what's ruining this country.  Everywhere you go, it's the same.  No goddamn  respect. Tim lets out a huge BELCH as he finishes drinking his bre

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (continuing) See what I'm talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: You'll never pass that exam on an empty  stomach, Kara. Debra snatches the book out of Kara's hands.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: (continuing; reading) Cognitive Therapy and Emotional Disorders?   What are they teaching in college these days?   The art of going crazy?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: (indignant) It's called psychology, Mom.  Living in this  house is what's driving me crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who the hell told you to come live here in the  first place? Kara rises, collects her books, trying to avoid a confron

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I'd better get Danny to school.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She don't show her face for five years, then  expects us to roll out the red carpet.  You  think going to college is gonna make up for  your mistakes, girl?

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: John, please don't --

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yo', just lay off her, Dad. Suddenly Danny runs in, showing off in his dinosaur costu ROARING loudly.  Startling John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What the fuck -- Kara immediately seizes Danny's hand and ushers him towar door.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Let's go, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: Kara, wait.  John.  Can't we all just sit  down?  Try to be a family for once?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mom. Debra reaches into her purse and hands Kara a couple of d

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's it, Debra, keep slipping her the cash.   While you're at it, why don't you just give her  all our goddamn money?! John explodes, dumping the entire contents of her purse o floor.  Debra recoils.  Kara steps in.  Danny is terrifie

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Stay away from her, you bastard.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (re Danny) I only see one bastard in this house. Kara flies at him with Medea-like rage.  John instantly g the neck and shoves her violently against the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Dad!  Let her go!

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: John!  Stop it!  Stop it! Danny looks outside.  Frozen in horror.  A VOICE whispers

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERING VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Kill him, Danny ... Kill him ... Danny moves across the kitchen.  Mesmerized.  Through the door, the Shape can be seen standing in the back yard. Kara's eyes bulge as John squeezes her throat.  Choking h

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You ever raise your hand to me again, I'll kill  you, you understand? John looks down to see the tip of a butcher knife pointed groin.  Danny is holding it -- his eyes dark, emotionless slowly, John releases Kara.  Debra and Tim watch in horri astonishment. Suddenly there's a KNOCK at the back door.  Kara dives to Danny.  The knife clatters to the floor as she picks him her book bag and hurtles outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH, 19, very "retro," cute in the waifish sense -- milk skin, two-tone hair and a dangling nose ring --is nearly the back porch as Kara and Danny fly out the door.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Make way for the Hardin County Express.  (following them across the yard) Hey, where's Tim?  We're supposed to go over  the list of events for tonight -- Beth is taken aback when she sees the bruise on Kara's ne

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (continuing) He do that to you?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Another episode of 'Daddy Knows Best' at the  Strode house.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Pig.  What the hell happened this time? Suddenly Tim jumps out from behind a clothesline, locking around Beth, attacking her with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hold on, hot lips.  We got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Shit, Beth, why do we have to be the ones to  organnize this friggin' fair? It's only  Halloween. Beth shoves the clipboard at him, a champion of her cause

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: How many times o I have to tell you? It's not  about Halloween.  It's about being political.   There are too many people with corn-cobs up  their ass in this town telling us what we can  and can't do.  If we want change, it's up to us  to set an example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debra is on the floor, stifling her tears, putting things her purse.  John stares coldly out the window.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I want her and that kid out of here tonight. Debra rises, facing him scornfully.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: I thought inheriting your father's house ...  the business ... moving out here might change  things.  But you're still the same, John.  (with finality) Kara has come home, and I'll be damned if I let  you turn her away again. Debra storms off.  John bores holes into her with his eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim lifts Danny into the back seat of Beth's convertible plastered with "Greenpeace" and "This is Your Brain on Dr stickers.  Kara and Beth in front.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Whatever happened to women in back?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Reality check, dillweed.  This is 1995. Pulling away from the curb, Beth honks at MRS. BLANKENSHI 80, owner of the student boarding house across the street

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (continuing) See you tonight, Mrs. Blankenship! The old woman just stares forward.  A gardem hose in hand waters a garden of long-dead flowers. Kara shields her eyes, distracted, looking up at the old house. KARA'S P.O.V. Beth drives down a shady, tree-lined avenue, unaware of t van that is following them.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Beth, who's that guy that lives across the hall  from you?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Why?  You interested?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: No!  I keep seeing him staring out his window.   Watching me.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You mean Tommy.  Yeah, on the weirdness scale  he's about an eleven.  Supposedly some scary  shit happened to him when he was a kid.  Messed  up his head.  He's harmless, though.  Probably  just lonely. Tim leans forward, ravaging Beth's neck.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Or horny.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Tim, do you always have to act like such an  asshole?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Only when you're around to dump on ... Hey,  chill, sis.  I'm just doggin' ya. Suddenly the van ROARS by and cuts them off.  Beth lays o HORN.  Slams on the brakes.  Narrowly avoiding a collisio

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Speed kills, asshole! Suddenly the van swerves around to face the VW head on. breathless moment the van and the VW sit at opposite ends intersection.  Idling.  A tense stand-off.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Who is that ... Kara strains to get a look at the van's driver.  A moment of a pale white face behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (bravely) I've got my pepper spray. Danny sits frozen in the back seat.  Suddenly the van sho forward, tires SCREAMING.  Startled GASPS.  The van turns sharply at the last second, SCREECHING down the next bloc

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (relieved) Happy fuckin' Halloween.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Someone's trying to scare us out of having this  fair ... and it's not gonna work. Beth drives on, grimly determined.  Kara looks back at Da returns her frightened gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy paces in his cramped apartment.  Dark circles under A remote control in hand, reviewing his recording of last Harry Simms broadcast:

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So they're trying to kill you and your baby.   Don't tell me.  Your name also happens to be  Rosemary.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, please listen!  They're coming ... coming  for me and my baby.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come on, sweetheart -- what is this? Who's  coming?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's ... Michael ... Michael Myers! Frustrated, Tommy plays it again.  Adjusts the speed.  Tr out something else in the b.g.  Jamie's voice comes throu Eerie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (continuing; slowed) It's ... Michael ... Michael Myers! Another VOICE, distant and distorted, filters up behind h

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bus 611 from Russellville now arriving. Tommy quickly stops the tape, throws on his worn leather jacket and bolts straight out the door. MOVE IN on a pair of old newspaper clippings left on the Headlines read:  "November 5, 1989.  JAMIE LLOYD STILL MI "November 19, 1989.  MYERS' NIECE PRESUMED DEAD."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy drives like a bat out of hell.  The "Greyhound" sig ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Explorer pulls up to the depot.  Tommy makes a beelin entrance, cowboy boots splashing through rain puddles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy wades his way through a small crowd up to the ticke cross-eyed ATTENDANT greets him.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Can I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Can you tell me if a bus arrived from  Russellville last night? The Attendant checks her roster.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Sure did.  About seven hours ago.  You lookin'  for someone --

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (walking away) Thank you. The Attendant eyes Tommy suspiciously as he enters the ph in the corner.  Inside, he picks up the receiver and pret dial a number.  Makes a cursory inspection.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: On the floor, tiny droplets of what appear to be blood fo trail out the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: follows the crimson path around the corner down a dim hal stopping at the door marked "Ladies Room."  Checking firs sure the coast is clear, he steps furtively inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy walks past the sink.  Water drips into the filthy b touches something inside, rubs it on his fingers -- blood Tommy whirls, startled by a sudden NOISE.  Muffled, indis Like CRYING.  Tommy gathers his courage as he slowly move long row of empty stalls.  The CRIES grow louder as he re final stall.  Jamie's escape route -- the window -- still A hole in the wall behind the toilet.  Tommy reaches in, locking onto something.  Shock and amazement overcome him lifts out a baby -- Jamie's baby.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Jesus ... The helpless newborn kicks and CRIES, the triangular symb still caked in blood over his tiny torso. SUBJECTIVE P.O.V. Someone partially opens the door, peering in from the hal Tommy removes his jacket and bundles the baby inside.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Okay, little guy.  You're okay.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: A CREAK.  Tommy looks up.  The door slowly closes.

dialogues.speaker: DEPOT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Tommy looks into shadowy stillness.  No one there.  Hidin cradling his jacket, he hurries through the crowd and sli door marked ENTRANCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of THWACKING BLADES as we FLY past a winding ru over a dense grove of oak trees -- massive, ancient guard sprawling pumpkin patch that lies beyond. As we circle the field, red-and-blue gum machines -- poli fire engines and ambulances -- can be seen through gauzy rising BLACK SMOKE, dissipating with the strong WIND. Charred in the ground, three intersecting lines stretch a feet across the plan to form a vivid geoglyphic.  The sym Thorn.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER PILOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Chopper One to Smith's Grove.  We've got a  visual.  Approximately ten miles due east of  Haddonfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loomis surveys the crash site with morbid fascination.  W wearing headphones, shouts over the noise.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: (pointing) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: It's a sign.  He's come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter lands, windmilling gusts of ashen earth. Wynn jump out, ducking past the spinning blades. We FOLLOW them through EMERGENCY CREWS and a few CURIOSIT toward the center of attention.  A charred body is lifted eviscerated, flame-blackened pikcup truck. A few feet away, a team of PARAMEDICS work frantically ar another body, hidden among a cluster of pumpkins. Loomis surges forward, at once halted by an armed DEPUTY.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Sir, you'll have to step back.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Please.  I need to see the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Official business. Wynn flashes his badge.  The Deputy gives them a vexed gl

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Wait here. Loomis's eyes flicker with nervous anticipation.  The Dep whispers something to SHERIFF JIM HOLDT, a brooding giant who dons a Stetson, holstered .44 Special and steel-toed give new meaning to the term "bad ass." Even Loomis steps back as the sheriff lumbers toward them

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: (extends his hand) You must be Sheriff Holdt. Holdt responds by stubbing out his Marlboro at Loomis's f

dialogues.speaker: HOLDT
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I am.  And I take it  you're the infamous Dr. Loomis.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I'd like to introduce you to Terence Wynn, the  Chief of Staff at --

dialogues.speaker: HOLDT
dialogues.text: Smith's Grove.  They told me you'd be coming.   Now I suggest you fly right on back to your  crackpot asylum.  You people got no business in  my town.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Michael Myers is my business. Holdt towers above him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDT
dialogues.text: I want you to listen and listen good, Loomis.   Things have been quiet for six years and that's  the way they're gonna stay.  The last thing we  need is you spouting off your ghost stories. As usual, Loomis isn't easily intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I suppose it was a ghost that did all this.  A  ghost who called the radio station last night.   Maybe that same ghost is lying over there right  now. Holdt fumes, ready to boil when --

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Sheriff!  She's alive! Holdt and Loomis wade through the crush of paramedics, ru alongside the stretcher being whisked toward an ambulance A large knife extruding from a girl's stomach, packed und gauze.  Skin pasty-white.  Lips blue from shock.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Dear God ... Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth's car pulls into the parking lot of a picturesque, i landscaped campus, speckled with colorful leaves.  A buzz excitement fills the autumn air. Tim and Beth are surprised to see a small crowd -- camped sleeping bags, holding "We Love to Hate Harry" signs.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yo, check it out.  They've been lining up all  night just to see Harry.  (to Kara) You lose your mind in that thing, Kara? Kara is nervously rifling through her enormous book bag.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I can't find my term paper.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So copy someone else's.  I do it all the time.   Works primo. Armed with her clipboard, Beth is assailed by her COMMITT Inundating her with QUESTIONS.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Give us victory or give us death.  See you  tonight, Kara! Tim and Beth are swept away.  A large sheet of paper fall Kara's bag.  She picks it up, startled by what she sees.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING
dialogues.text: Crayola figures of Grandma, Grandpa, Uncle Tim, and Mommy piercing them.  Blood dripping.  Mouths screaming.  A bla figure bearing the word "THORN." On the flip side, the drawing she found last night.  Dann scribbling of the odd triangular symbol.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The horrifying images send chills up Kara's spine.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Thorn ... Lost in grim reverie, Kara walks on, oblivious to the act around her ... A banner hangs from the eaves of the library:  "HADDONFIE

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE
dialogues.text: Tim and Beth supervise as preparations for tonight's even underway. STUDENT VOLUNTEERS nailing together booths, hanging decor half-assembled Ferris wheel, a merry-go-round, an ominous House of Horrors. Rounding the corner onto the quiet path behind the librar suddenly finds herself alone.  WIND whips at her hair.  S over her shoulder, as if sensing a presence. KARA'S P.O.V. No one is there.  Just the rustling of leaves on the grou

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Walking off in the distance.  Suddenly the Shape steps sh into FRAME, watching her disappear around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors BLAST open.  The stretcher holding Jamie is pushed Loomis right beside her.  Wynn follows, trying to stop hi SHOCK-TRAUMA unit swarms in.  No time to lose.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC
dialogues.text: Penetrating abdominal trauma.  Massive blood  loss.  We've given her two units of O-negative  stat and dextran.  BP sixty.  Pulse one-twenty  ... Somehow she pulled through out there all  night! DR. BONHAM, the ER resident, peels off the sheet, exposin sea of blood around the enormous knife still jutting from stomach.  Bonham stares, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BONHAM
dialogues.text: How can this girl still be alive?! Type and  cross-match for another six units!  Get a CT  scan and move her into surgery.  (re Loomis and Wynn) And get them out of here! ORDERLIES move in.  Loomis won't release Jamie's hand.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: Sam, don't -- let them take care of her.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I'm here now, Jamie.  You're going to live.   You have to.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL ENTRANCE / ADMITTANCE DESK
dialogues.text: Pneumatic doors fly open.  Tommy bursts through, holding his jacket.  PATIENTS and COPS everywhere.  He hones in o behind the admittance desk.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I need to see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I-it's a baby -- my baby.  There's been -- been  an accident.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: What kind of an accident?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (explodes) Just get me a doctor right now!

dialogues.speaker: ADJACENT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Wynn and Loomis skirt past a line of SECURITY GUARDS.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: There's nothing more you can do for her. The shrill sound of Wynn's beeper.  He clicks it.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'll be right back. Wynn disappears around the corner.  Loomis wanders off al

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Dr. Loomis! Loomis reacts, taken aback by the frantic young man bound him.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Dr. Loomis, thank God you're here.  You heard  her, didn't you?  It was Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but do I know you --

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I'm Tommy.  Tommy Doyle.  Laurie Strode --  Jamie's mother -- she was baby-sitting for me  that night -- Loomis suddenly recognizes him.  It's been a very long ti

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Yes ... Tommy.  What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Please -- just tell me the truth.  Has Michael  Myers come home? Loomis pulls Tommy aside into an empty alcove.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: What do you know about Michael?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I know he's alive.  People in this town -- they  want us to believe he's dead.  But I know.   I've always known.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Right now at least one girl is dead and Jamie  Lloyd is in there fighting for her life.  She  is the last of his blood line.  If she dies --

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (gravely) No, Dr. Loomis.  She's not the last night. Tommy hesitates.  Loomis's eyes are drawn enigmatically t infant in Tommy's arms.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (continuing; startled realization) Oh, God -- his cousins.  The Strodes. They're  living in the Myers house! Loomis's face flls with horror.  Tommy sees the Admittanc flanked by a pair of security guards, walking his way.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I gotta go. Tommy bolts toward the exit.  Loomis tries to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Tommy, wait! But he is gone.  A hand taps Loomis's shoulder; he reels.

dialogues.speaker: WYNN
dialogues.text: There you are.  Who was that boy?

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: An old friend. Darkness fills Loomis's countenance as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We peer OVER THE SHOULDER of the Shape, standing across t Watching Debra, in jeans and a rumpled sweatshirt, collec left-over painting supplies from the front porch. Debra starts to open the CREAKY screen door when she noti John had used earlier.  Clumsily picks it up and slides i the top of the crate she is holding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laden with her heavy load, Debra nudges the door shut wit foot.  Then crosses to another door -- the cellar door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debra, silhouetted at the top of the stairs, hits a light naked bulb springs to life.  Slowly she descends the rick staircase. The basement, pitch dark save for a spear of sunlight sho through an elevated window, is overrun with cobwebs, rust and broken bicycle parts.  A clunker of a washing machine the corner. Debra makes space for the crate in a storage cabinet.  Su washing machine stops.  Nonplissed, she moves toward it. lid.  The bed sheets inside are sopping wet. Opening the electrical fuse box, she flicks a switch back a few times -- but the washing machine doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: Great. Frustrated, Debra looks down to see a large puddle of wat on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debra hauls a laundry basket upstairs, filled with wet sh turns, startled.  The front door is standing wide open. Just as she goes to shut it, a man steps out from the liv behind her.  She gasps, dropping the basket; it's Loomis.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, Mrs. Strode. Debra shudders at the sight of the beguiling, wide-eyed m

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've been knocking.  The door was open. Is  everything all right in here?

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: (defensively) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I've come to help your family. Debra steps aside as Loomis walks in right past her.  Hol valuminous file bearing the name "MICHAEL AUDREY MYERS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of JANGLING KEYS.  A door UNLOCKING.  Tommy scr the baby iin one arm, a bag of groceries under the other. With a single swipe, he clears away the junk on his futin carefully lays down the CRYING infant.  He digs through t Baby Wipes.  Diapers.  Formula.  Bottles.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Shhh.  Okay, okay, Kyle.  You like that name?   Yeah, I think it suits you. Quickly he scans the directions on the formula.  Pours th into a bottle, nukes it in the microwave, then returns to business at hand. Tommy grimaces at the mess inside his leather bomber.  Th CRIES harder.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is worse for me than it is for you. Armed with Baby Wipe and a diaper, Tommy goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY, (SAME)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Blankenship traverses the hall outside Tommy's apart baby's CRIES; Tommy's GROSSED-OUT GROANS can clearly be h the old woman keeps walking, oblivious to it all.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY'S APARTMENT, (SAME)
dialogues.text: Tommy finishes securing the diaper.  The baby in his arms the formula's temperature and feeds him.  The infant suck voraciously.  The crying stops.  Tommy rocks him gently.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It's okay, big guy.  Don't you worry. I'm gonna  take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loomis, setting out the case file on Michael Myers -- gru photographs of the murder scenes -- has Debra's undivided

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Michael Myers was just six-years-old when he  stabbed his sister to death in 1963.  Here in  this house.  For the next fifteen years, I  became obsessed with finding out what was  living inside of him.  He was my lift's work  and my ultimate failure.  I knew what he was  but I never knew why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara sits in the front row of a classrooom as a PROFESSOR on.  He looks at Kara, something frightening in his gaze. as her pen glides dreamily over her notebook.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's a living force inside of him. Driving  him.  And I fear that somehow it has been  unleashed again.

dialogues.text: An entire page of scribbled triangles.  The mark of Thorn

dialogues.text: Who's my next victim? The other kids make way as Danny takes the empty spot on tetherball court, sitting face-to-face with the inplacabl Danny says nothign as he places his bet and slams the sta Pogs.  Ian glowers.  Easy money.  The showdown begins.

dialogues.text: Loomis vivdly reenacts the nightmare as Debra shows him u

dialogues.text: He crept up these stairs and made his way into  this room.  His sister's room. Right here.   Where it all began.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: (near tears) What makes you think he'll come here again?

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: This house is sacred to him.  It's the source  of his memories -- his rage.  Mrs. Strode, I  beg you.  Don't let your family suffer the same  fast as Laurie and her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: Jamie?  But I thought she was --

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Found this morning.  In a field outside  Haddonfield.  Stabbed.

dialogues.text: Dr. Bonham and his team surround Jamie, anesthetized on t operating table, her condition weak but stable. Blood flows from the gaping wound in her abdomen.  Slowly painstakingly, the knife is extracted. A NURSE takes a sample of a thick, viscous fluid from ben Jamie's gown and holds it up to the light for the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny wins another round.  His till growing.  More kids g watch.  Ian is losing his cool, determined to save face.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Double or nothing. Danny pushes over the stack, nothing incisive in his mann retorts, angrily slamming his Pogs.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look how he sits there.  Little freak. Just  like the bogeyman who used to live in his  house.  Are you the bogeyman, Danny? Ian trumps Danny's hand and smiles haughtily.  The low, w VOICE which only Danny can hear RUMBLES in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: WHISPERING VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Kill him, Danny ... Kill him now ... Danny stares blankly across the playground. DANNY'S P.O.V. The white van is parked across the street.  A tall figure stands beside it, watching Danny.  The Stranger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara sits glued behind a computer monitor, the glow of th reflected in her reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This force which drives him, which keeps him  alive, comes from something more powerful --  more deadly than we can possibly imagine.  The  embodiment of all that is evil. KARA'S P.O.V. A litany of topics scroll up the screen.  Kara punches in them.  Card catalog entry reads:  "Thorn:  The Devil's Ru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spellbound, Danny slams down the winning Pog.  Methodical dumps the money in his Halloween bag and begins to walk a Ian sees red.  Written across Danny's last Pog:  "DIE, FA

dialogues.text: You crazy little freak!!! Ian goes berserk, leaping out at Danny like an enraged li kids cheer him on as a full-fledged playground brawl ensu Danny breaks away.  Runs.  With an amazing burst of stren swings a tetherball.  Th ball CRACKS Ian right between hi laying the bully flat on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debra leads Loomis to the front door, her face clouded wi

dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Lock the doors and call your husband. Get your  family as far away from Haddonfield as  possible.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: God ... this can't be true.

dialogues.speaker: LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Strode, Michael Myers is here to kill his  family.  And he won't stop until you are all  destroyed.  I only thank God that I found you  before he did. Loomis grips her hand reassuringly, then heads out the do turns the deadbolt, securing it with the chain lock.  She against the wall, tears of horror in her eyes.

Danny takes off running toward the gate. Suddenly he barrels into the outstretched hands of a towe shape.  Danny looks up in shock at a stone-faced man -- T

dialogues.text: MOVING with Kara through long rows of books -- a veritabl of knowledge.  She comes down a deserted aisle, searching spotting what she is looking for. She pulls out an old, dusty tome and begins flipping thro pages. As she reads we SEE the cover:  "Runes and Ancient Black

dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING.  A modest, one-story building located in th business section of town.  Cheap Halloween decorations ha windows.  An "OPEN" sign on the front door. MOANS of ecstasy resound along the street, attracting the of the mid-day passerby.

dialogues.text: I'm coming.  Yes.  I'm coming.  Get ready.  I'm  coming.  Oh, yes!  Yesss!!! The WKNB station van rolls by; another Harry Simms plug. people laugh.  Others wince in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SIMMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Made ya look!!!  I'm coming, all right. And you  better be there.  Tonight.  Let's do it  together.

dialogues.text: A sparesely-furnished office screaming for renovation.  B obviously slow.  John rattles a jammed file cabinet, then in a fit of angry frustration before answering the incess RINGING phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (barking) Strode Realty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debra on the other end.  Tears reddening her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: John, it's me.  Something terrible has  happened. INTERCUT their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What is it this time?

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: A man came by the house.  A psychiatrist by the  name of Loomis. John stiffens, slowly sits down behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: (continuing) He told me about the terrible things that  happened here.  In our house.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing letting strangers  in without --

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: (releasing) John, they sound Jamie Lloyd this morning!   Someone tried to kill her!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What in God's name are you talking about,  woman?  When are you gonna stop listening to  those damned talk shows?

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: I'm getting the children out of here. At least  until we know what we're dealing with.  John, I  want you to come with us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (whispers) Debra, you're fuckin' insane.

dialogues.speaker: DEBRA
dialogues.text: You knew, didn't you, John?  You knew. A CLICK as the line suddenly goes DEAD. John scowls, opens his lower desk drawer, produces a bott and a small glass.  He blows off dust and begins to pour.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Trick-or-treat to you, too.
